org.naomi.regex

Class CharClass

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.naomi.regex.Pattern
      • org.naomi.regex.CharClass
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AlterationListener
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BuiltInCharClass, CollectionCharClass, DelegateCharClass, ExplicitCharClass, FilterCharClass, IntersectCharClass, IntervalCharClass, UnionCharClass

    public abstract class CharClass
extends Pattern
    An instance of any subclass of this abstract class is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character in the set of characters that define that instance.

    That is, a CharClass is defined by a set of characters (though it is not a java.util.Set), any one of which can be matched in the target string on each repetition of the Pattern (the number of repetitions being controlled by private but user-settable MinCount and MaxCount values, whose defaults are both 1). For example: 

            pat1 = new ExplicitCharClass("abc");
        pat1.setMinAndMaxCount(1,1);    // redundantly restating the defaults
    matches only "a" or "b" or "c" whereas 

            pat1to4 = new ExplicitCharClass("abc");
        pat1to4.setMinAndMaxCount(1,4);
    matches "a", "b", "aa", "aaa", "ba", "abc", "cbb", "aabb", "abcb", etc.

    That is, pat1to4 matches anywhere from 1 to 4 characters in a row, where each character must be one of "a", "b", or "c".

    CharClass allows the user to define subsets of characters that are to be matched, where these subsets can be derived from pre-defined ("BuiltIn") sets of characters, strings of characters (interpreted as sets--as in the pat1 and pat1to4 examples above), ranges of characters, Java Collections or Iterators, or the unions, intersections, or complements of other CharClasses. The subclasses IntersectCharClass and UnionCharClass, the CharClass method getComplement(), and an internal "Not" flag (in all CharClass subclasses except IntersectCharClass and UnionCharClass) allow the creation of CharClasses that are arbitrary boolean combinations of other CharClasses.

    Note that a CharClass is quite different from a CharSequencePattern, which matches an entire sequence of characters, such as the string "abc" or "Naomi" (once per repetition).

        public String toString()
